content.description:
A fantastic pitch of ice in an awesome setting that is the gateway to a full alpine adventure if you so choose.

Climb low angle ice to the base of a steep curtain, pull through the curtain for about 10-15 meters of vertical climbing which then eases off. Surmount a couple more steps and belay at a 3 bolt anchor on a rock outcrop on the left. Either rappel the route with 70m ropes or continue left and up the wide ledge to Consciousness and the top of Nachtmahr. 

You could break this up into 2 smaller pitches without a 70m rope.


Access the climb from the James Lake trailhead (51.745369, -115.362015) located on the north side of the Yaha Tinda Road west of Sundre.

From the trailhead follow the old quad trail east along the creek bed all the way to Eagle Lake. Cross Eagle Lake to far (east) side where you pick up the old quad trail again. Follow the trail to the southwest end of James Lake.

Catch glimpses through the trees of A Dream Come True and Nachtmahr on your right high up in a drainage on Maze Peak as you approach James Lake about 1km after leaving Eagle Lake.

Once at the southwest end of James Lake cut off the quad trail and head southeast through the trees trending right until you hit the the drainage that A Dream Come True is located on. Follow the gully the whole way up to the base of the climb. A shorter but much less obvious approach is possible off the trail about 300 meters before you hit James Lake. Turning straight south and bushwacking about 150 meters through trees will bring you to the large and rocky drainage leading to A Dream Come True.

Standard ice rack, bolted anchor.

Another Dream is the left hand climb found at the Y junction after climbing several steps of ice above the top of Dream On.

Climb rambling ice through the pinch in the canyon to the base of a pillar, pull through the short pillar to the top.

It is possible to continue on from the top of Another Dream to several more pitches of ice high up terminating at tree line under a large bowl.

Climb Dream On, and continue up multiple WI2-3 steps (bolts for anchors are present for every step if needed) to a obvious Y junction in the gully. If you are in the right place you will be able to see both This Dream is Over (on the right) and Another Dream (on the left) from the same spot.
Standard ice rack.

Consciousness is the continuation of A Dream Come True and worth doing to extend the day or continue further up to Dream Eater for a full alpine adventure.

After climbing A Dream Come True, traverse left over a large scree/snow ledge to the top of Nachtmahr. Slog up another 50 meters or so of snow to the base of Consciousness.

Climb a steep step to easier ice above giving way to snow. Walk around the rock band up and right to belay off a tree.



See approach beta for A Dream Come True and climb it.

Standard ice rack to a tree belay.

Dream Eater is found high on Maze Peak and accessed only by climbing A Dream Come True and ConsciousnessÂ and then continuing up the hanging valley found above for a full alpine day. Climb a steep and potentially thin pillar for 15m until the angle eases off, continue to right before the ice ends and build an ice belay. Either rappel the route and descend the way you came or continue and navigate snow and easy rock to the summit of Maze Peak. Climb A Dream Come True and Consciousness, continue up and left at the junction until you are below a scree/snow slope. Cut up this slope aiming for a break in the cliffband which allows you to gain another scree slope on the ridge. Traverse this slope trending left until Dream Eater comes into view. Slog up the gully to the base. Standard ice rack to an ice belay.

A hidden gem of WI4 ice.

Pitch 1: Climb 35 meters of rolling WI2-3 ice that narrows at the top to a couple meters in width. Bolted anchor on the right.

Cross the big snow ledge for 20 meters or so and set up a belay.

Pitch 2: Climb 35 meters of steepening ice until the last 10 meter crux pillar, pull through and clip bolted anchors directly ahead of you.

Descend: 2 rappels gets you back to the bottom, one won't do it even with 70m ropes due to the size of the ledge separating the two pitches.

Cross Eagle Lake and follow the obvious trail through the trees Eastward until you can see the route on your left, cut through the trees directly to the base.
Standard ice rack. Bolted anchors.

climbs.name: Nachtmahr
climbs.fa: Rich Akitt, Marcus Norman, Lyle Rotter, Raphael Slawinski, January 20, 2013

content.description: Description directly from Raphael Slawinski's blog. Posted here for completeness of info for the area. This is a cool (I think it's cool, anyway), fully mixed route located in a rarely visited corner of the Rockies. It sits on the northeast aspect of Maze Peak in the Dry Ranges, overlooking James Lake and the prairies to the east. More than likely you'll have the whole place to yourself. The route does not appear to come in every year, so go check it out soon - who knows when it'll be in next? A rack of 6 draws, 8 shoulder-length slings and 6 or so screws is all that's needed. From the Eagle Lake/James Pass parking lot (see the driving directions for Dream On for how to get there), hike east on a quad trail. Easy walking across the frozen Eagle Lake, past Dream On and the other assorted Dream climbs on the left (north) side of the valley, takes you over James Pass to James Lake. Just before you reach James Lake leave the trail and hike right (south) 200 or so vertical metres to the base of the route. 2 hours. Pitch 1 (30 m, WI4-5): A number of lines are possible, ranging from thinnish low-angle ice on the left to overhanging mushrooms in the centre. Belay from screws at the top left of the bottom ice flow. Pitch 2 (25 m, M9): Move right to a small pillar and the first bolt. From the top of the pillar follow bolts left underneath a roof. Pull over the roof with a few big moves on small holds and continue more easily to a patch of ice. The ring-bolt station at its top is threatened by falling ice from the next pitch, so it's better to continue another few metres over a rock arch to a sheltered bolt belay on the right. Pitch 3 (30 m, M7 WI5): A couple of big reaches on small holds gain a dagger (harder if broken off) and easier climbing up the right edge of a curtain. In spite of its large size the curtain does not appear to be very well attached to the rock. Given one of the first ascentionists' history with collapsing ice, this pitch was also equipped with bolts. Belay at a bolted station a few metres back from the lip on the right. Rappel the route in 2 double-rope raps: the first from the top station, the second from the ring-bolt station near the top of pitch 2 (ignore a bad bolt a couple of metres to the right).Â  6 draws, 8 shoulder-length slings and 6 or so screws

The steep ice pillar pouring out of the cliff band directly between Nachtmahr and A Dream Come True. Climb 45m of steep ice to the top of the pillar, rappel from a v thread. The shortest approach is to drive up Hwy 40 N and park as for the James Lake trailhead at 51.745369, -115.362015.

From the trailhead follow the old quad trail along the creek bed all the way to James Lake.

Once at the southwest end of James Lake cut off the quad trail and head through the trees trending right until you hit the obvious gully. Follow the gully the whole way up to the base of the climb. Standard ice rack.

An obscure line well above Dream On. 

40 meters of ice that can vary in condition, climb increasingly steepening ice until the last 10 meters which formed unconsolidated and mushroomed on our ascent. Pull over the top to an anchor of a slung rock pillar on the left. 

Rappel off the anchor back to the base.

Climb Dream On, and continue up multiple WI2-3 steps (bolts for anchors are present for every step if needed) to a obvious Y junction in the gully. If you are in the right place you will be able to see both This Dream is Over (on the right) and Another Dream (on the left) from the same spot.
Standard ice rack.

James Pass is an easily accessible valley containing Eagle Lake and James Lake, hemmed in by Maze Peak and Eagle Mountain to the south and north, and lots of ice on either side. The most popular route in the area is Dream On, although there are other worthwhile obscurities and adventures to be had as well. You will likely have the valley to yourself so this area is a great option to get away from the crowds.
